comments.commentBody:
Just tough enough. Doable but not without some effort. I enjoyed solving this one on Thanksgiving evening.

Enjoy your weekend.
This is what this paper wants to turn us into in our own country -- foreigners with no rights.

Have you seen the almost inhumane spaces where domestic workers are forced to sleep in? Also bonuses for domestic workers are not mandatory and food allowances barely cover decent meals in Hk. Most of importantly, you fail to note the because domestic workers are forced to live with their employers, there is no law prohibiting them from working 24/6.

Any day now: the Chinese will suddenly recognize the error of their ways and wholeheartedly embrace democracy; the Western world will suddenly recognize the error of their ways and lose their fear of the industrious Chinese. Any day now.

Do you believe in God? Then there are 5x more Chinese than Americans and maybe we should shut up and watch. Every Chinese person is worth as much as any American, period, in God's eyes. I do not endorse or even accept the CCCP, but the reality is that they have lifted more people out of poverty and despair than we could even dream of. Shut. Up.

There does seem to be a thriving middle class in China now. Not sure there was one before. Mao's family was classified as "upper middle peasant." I'm not sure my American family would have been considered economically "upper" in anything.

Chinese are now consumed with acquiring houses, cars, jewelry, education, material, of any kind. There are also more churches. Temples are bring restored Spiritual interests are also increasing.

Democracy? Doubt it will ever work in China without a fantastic spiritual revival first. People must have an interest in other than themselves for democracy to work. Communist or not, China is a much better place to live than America in many respects.
The press uses erroneusly "middle class" to identify w/China's global consumer class about top5%. China's middle class 75-200% median income spans from UN def of Poverty $3.80/day up.
Can not overstate that China will not become more like the West as it becomes stronger. Much to the contrary. That's a good thing in many ways.

For most of the past 2200 years China has been an ethnic Han socioeconomic political educational scientific technological world superpower ruling with the "Mandate of Heaven" from the Central/Middle Kingdom. From the Mongols to the Manchus to the British to the Japanese challengers to Han supremacy have come and gone to their grief.

Will the "Beautiful Country" as America is known in Mandarin be the next stuffed souvenir for the People's Republic of China?

Chinese President XI Jinping shares a privileged prince patrimony with Donald Johnson Trump. Xi Jinping's father was a legendary Long March veteran colleague of Mao Zedong. Trump wisely picked a multimillionaire real estate baron father. Xi Jinping rose to the top of the one party term limited collective leadership governing party military leadership in a rising China. The Donald will be man handled by this man in a rising complex dragon of a nation of 1.3 billion souls. By comparison the 143 million Russians are led by a whiny bear cub named Vladimir Putin.

"The East is Red" was the prophesy of Mao Zedong after 30 million Chinese died under the onslaught of the Imperial Japanese Rising Sun during World War II. I hope not. But stay tuned.
For most of the past 2200 years there has been no such entity called "China."
Xi- not a president, he was not elected. Korea, Taiwan, Philippines, etc leaders are voted by the people.

Do most of us feel this way? Or this arrogance is misplaced -
"Chinese saw America as a place that could save China from the depredations of other imperialist nations and, with its world-class educational system, as a model for China to emulate. "
Trade has been good for us. But change a people - we want to think of Iraq and so many more before China. Hello there!

It should be pointed out that after the Chinese revolution of 1911, the Chinese greatly admired the US and its political system, but Woodrow Wilson's racist policy at the 1919 Paris Conference alienated the Asians. As a result, China sought salvation from the newly victorious Bolsheviks, while Japan went on to become ultranationalist and fascist.

Thank you, Mr. Pomfret, for acknowledging that "engagement" has been a massive failure. I will read your book with great interest.
I can't make it to DC but would love to ask you one thing:
Do you think the most ardent proponents of engagement really thought our trillions in FDI would democratize China or that they used that as a cynical selling point in order to get at that cheap labor?

Thank you

11/24 1:27pm

@trblmkr
The mentioned “trillions in FDI”were American, and other, private enterprises shifted to China in search of cheap labor and higher profits by selling imports. You will find no social consciousness in those transactions, only blatant desire for the bottom line, but the Engagement mentioned was the Western concept, not uniquely American, that History Is Over; Marketization will rule and that somehow, by developing a middle class, will Democratize the world – in simplest terms – make Them like Us.
From comments section you will still see that one living on.

Remember the "Great East Asia Co-properity Sphere" that Japanese had promoted and that lead to the attack on Hawaii? Is America going to withdraw to Hawaii and let the Chinese rules the Great East Asia?

is uncle sam the only nation allow to have his sphere of influence?

care to ask the central and south americans how much they benefit from regime change? cia covert operations? right wing dictatorship?

What kind of interaction with China from Trump and his minions would you expect when the Chinese are not white?  I am also curious how Trump will act when the Chinese don't go along with Trump or degrade him in some way.  Narcissists by nature will lash out and attempt to punish those they perceive as not see them as "Great".  You've see this lately with the media.  Trump believes he can punish and browbeat the media.

Unfortunately, the United States has set itself on a collision course with the non-western world.

There is a continuing arrogance that American ways are "better" for non-Americans, as well as an insistence, directly or subtly, that others adopt their moral code. This kind of supremacism is both unfounded and likely to end badly for the US, given its diversification and relative decline against multiple rising world powers.

Asia should be ruled by Asians. Its business conducted by Asians. The same goes for any other people in their regions of the world. This chauvinism is not only operationally correct, it is also morally just. It is America that has broken this basic respect for autonomy, usually in the name of democracy, liberalism, or something equally deplorable that they assume to be universal.

President Xi does not imply that all of Asia should be dominated by China, at most influenced by Chinese power and economics, the way it has been for millennia. It is United States that keeps military bases across the Asia-Pacific while accusing others of hegemony -- without any sense of hypocrisy, apparently.

If Mr. Trump is to be pragmatic, then he should seek to pivot away from Asia (and other places) in all ways except trade. In doing so, he will gain credibility in the eyes of the non-white, non-western world, in addition to dealing a mortal blow to the "globalists" he railed against throughout his campaign.
China gleefully accepted and still accepts trillions in "tainted" FDI from the "racist, supremacist" West. A strong argument could be made that China would be a failed state by now if it hadn't.

This phenomenon isn't only happening in Beijing.  Shanghai is the same - ten years ago most people there could communicate in standard "putonghua" Mandarin but spoke Shanghainese among themselves.  We spent this summer in Shanghai with our grade school children, who quickly found new friends in the local community playground. Much to my surprise, the local kids all spoke Mandarin among themselves, not Shanghainese. Their grandparents, summoning them home to dinner, would call out in Shanghainese. It's not hard to surmise that language diversity in China is dying.
British RP, "Received Pronunciation", is the politically correct term for the accent with which the Queen speaks.

Respectfully disagree with the notion that "the best Chinese is CCTV", much less that what their readers speak is "like BBC for British".

As for "better Mandarin", it seems to me that speaking any Chinese language--including dialects of Putonghua, such as Beijinghua, is about much more than "sounding like the readers on CCTV".

Excellent response (and well-founded on real knowledge of linguistics and the particular character of Beijinghua.

Here is another "Beijingism" to consider (I was having a great conversation with a native of Beijing just yesterday):

憋火兒 (bīehŭor, a ballast or starter used in fluorescent light tubes--usually rendered as 啟動器 , qǐdòngqì in Putonghua).
Go out to Long Island.

By any scientifically sound linguistics measure, Cantonese (Guangdonghua) is a separate language in the Han Chinese language group.

By the same standard, Beijinghua is a dialect, not an "accent".

To accept the notion that Cantonese (which is not intelligible to Mandarin speakers) is a "dialect" is to be swayed by a politically motivated narrative that is not scientifically valid.

'Putonghua, the now standard Mandarin, is an artificial dialect not actually spoken [by] the people.' No more artificial than standard Italian, based on Tuscan dialects spoken by the educated. As those familiar with Italy - like China, an ancient culture, with many local dialects, at times mutually unintelligible - will know, the standard national language, Italian, is the language one speaks with foreigners, i e, anyone who doesn't speak the local patois. The same thing is true of China. In both cases, the process of linguistic homogenisation has been hastened by universal primary education, radio, and more recently, television. Inevitable perhaps, but I must confess that hearing someone speaking genuine Romano, 北京土话, or, for that matter, västerbottniska here in Sweden, can bring tears of joy to my eyes....

Henri

Hi Chih Hsing, thanks for your comment. As Brendan points out below, the Beijing accent and dialect are two different but related things. The accent is quite common. The dialect - with its own grammatical structures, phrases, and names that are not translatable to standard Mandarin - is sadly fading. The full scope of the dialect couldn't be demonstrated within the full scope of this short article, so sorry for any confusion.
Received Pronunciation - the form of English spoken by BBC news readers and meant to be understood by all British regardless of their local accent.

Change is difficult for everyone.

I look back with fondness to my childhood days growing up in Chicago but also knowing that I never what to go back to those times. Instead I look forward to what tomorrow has to offer.

China with a population of 1.4 billion people, what is "standard" anything?

Even the written language isn't "standard".

Sure people living in Beijing might be able to read all the characters in a sentence written by a native Guangzhou person but they won't have a clue about the meaning.

Who cares?  That only creates bigger problem, the so called "divide & conquer." It separates & discriminates people from different places.  A big country like China with 56 ethnic groups is already tough enough to manage, why adds the local speaking tones to the already big problem?  I am sure every Chinese province has its own speaking tones.  Just image if US speaks 50 different tones (or pronunciation), one for each state, how could people communicate with each other?  Even without language barrier, California has succession petition after every election to be independent from US. Isn't that bad enough? Why tests China?

While we are lamenting the loss of Chinese dialects, we should not forget that the greatest insult to the Chinese language has already occurred.  Although well intention, the simplification of the characters had resulted in a significant loss of the meaning and beauty to the characters.  We now get a bowl of "face" (面) when we want a bowl of noddles (麵) and love without a heart (爱 instead of 愛).  What a pity!

The 1958 simplification did two other things as well:
A). It made many characters look almost the same
B). In a classic case of Communist dishonesty, the simplification drive was billed as something to increase literacy-- but actually its aim was to DECREASE the ability to read anything pre-1958, meaning anything old.
